pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.1.2: This refers to robe-cloth received during the robe-making season. For details see [](MS.3.1397-MS.3.1523).
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.1.4: For an explanation of this see [](MS.3.1396) and [](MS.3.1397-MS.3.1523).
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.2.5: I have here included three kinds of building—the _māḷa_, the _pāsāda_, and the _hammiya_—into one category, “stilt house.” See below for an explanation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.2.9: The Pali term _upacāra_ may mean ‘entrance’ or ‘neighborhood,’ and thus I vary the translation depending on the context.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.3.3: “Of the house” is added from [](Sp.1.477): _Hatthapāsā vā na vijahitabbanti atha vā taṃ gharaṃ samantato hatthapāsā na vijahitabbaṃ_. Without this explanation it is hard to make out whether the arm’s reach is from the house or from the robe. In each instance below I have added the respective commentarial explanation, found at [](Sp.1.477-Sp.1.494), so as to make it clear what the arm’s reach relates to.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.3.4: [](Sp.1.479): _… tesaṃyeva sabhāyadvāramūlānaṃ hatthapāsā vā na vijahitabbaṃ_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.3.5: [](Sp.1.479): _… sabhāye vā vatthabbaṃ dvāramūle vā, hatthapāsā vā na vijahitabbaṃ_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.3.6: [](Sp.1.479): _Sabhāye nikkhipitvā pana sabhāye vā tassa sammukhe nagaradvāramūle vā tesaṃyeva hatthapāse vā aruṇaṃ uṭṭhāpetabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.4.3: _Dvāramūle_. [](Sp.1.480) says: _Sabbesaṃ sādhāraṇe gharadvāramūle_, “At the base of that door of the house which is common to all.” [](Sp.1.480): _Hatthapāsā vāti gabbhassa vā gharadvāramūlassa vā hatthapāsā_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.5.1: _Uddosita_. [](Sp.1.482): _Udositoti yānādīnaṃ bhaṇḍānaṃ sālā_, “An _udosita_ is a shed for goods such as vehicles, etc.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.5.2: [](Sp.1.482): _Ito paṭṭhāya ca nivesane vuttanayeneva vinicchayo veditabbo_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.5.3: [](Sp.1.482): _Ito paṭṭhāya ca nivesane vuttanayeneva vinicchayo veditabbo_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.5.4: [](Sp.1.482): _Ito paṭṭhāya ca nivesane vuttanayeneva vinicchayo veditabbo_.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.7.1: The building at [](MS.1.1906), the _māḷa_, is hard to distinguish from the buildings mentioned in the next two paragraphs, the _pāsāda_ and the _hammiya_. In fact [](Sp.1.482) says they are all different kinds of _pāsāda_, that is, different kinds of “stilt houses”: _Māḷoti ekakūṭasaṅgahito caturassapāsādo. Pāsādoti dīghapāsādo. Hammiyanti muṇḍacchadanapāsādo_, “A _māḷa_ is a square stilt house with (a roof in) a single peak. A _pāsāda_ is a long stilt house. A _hammiya_ is a stilt house with a bare roof.” Rather than try to name each of these buildings, which in any case would not be useful for practical purposes, I have instead grouped them together as “stilt house.” (For why a _pāsāda_ is a stilt house, see [ref. to internet page].) For practical purposes, what these three buildings have in common—and this is what distinguishes them from the buildings at [](MS.1.1901-MS.1.1904), the _nivesana_ and the _uddosita_—is that they do not have an enclosed category.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.11.1: According to [](Sp.1.489): _Ekaṃ abbhantaraṃ aṭṭhavīsatihatthaṃ hoti_, “One _ abbhantara_ is twenty-eight _hatthas_.” Following my own estimate of the _hattha_ (see comment in _bhikkhu-saṅghādisesa_ 6) as 40 centimeters, this gives 11.2 meters for one _abbhantara_ and about 80 meters for 7.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.12.3: [](Sp.1.490): _Nānākulassa khette hatthapāso nāma khettadvārassa hatthapāso_. [](Sp-t.2.490): adds: _… dvāramūlato aññattha antokhettepi vasantena cīvaraṃ hatthapāse katvāyeva vasitabbaṃ_, which means, as one would expect, that staying within arm’s reach of the robe is also acceptable. The same holds for the next two categories of threshing floor and park.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.13.1: For the threshing floor and the next category of park, arm’s reach has the same meaning as for field, see [](Sp.1.491): _Dvīsupi khette vuttasadisova vinicchayo.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np2:3.17.1: That is, 7 _abbhantaras_. [](Sp.1.489): _Ekaṃ abbhantaraṃ aṭṭhavīsatihatthaṃ hoti_, “One _ abbhantara_ is twenty-eight _hatthas_.” My own estimate of the _hattha_ as 40 centimeters (see comment in _bhikkhu-saṅghādisesa_ 6) gives 11.2 metes for one _abbhantara_ and about 80 meters for 7. [](Sp.1.494) adds: _Samantā sattabbhantarāti majjhe ṭhitassa samattā sabbadisāsu sattabbhantarā, vinibbedhena cuddasa honti_, “_Samantā sattabbhantara_: for one standing in the middle, seven _abbhantaras_ in all directions, which is fourteen _abbhantaras_ across.” In other words, a circle with a radius of 80 meters.
